title: 108_hr1724
content: The Act titled "Reservist Opportunities and Protection of Education Act of 2003" allows for refunds and leave of absence for military service under the Higher Education Act of 1965. The Act "Reservist Opportunities and Protection of Education Act of 2003" mandates that institutions of higher education grant military leave of absence and provide refunds or credits to students called up for active duty. Students on military leave are entitled to be restored to their academic status upon completion of service. The "Reservist Opportunities and Protection of Education Act of 2003" requires institutions of higher education to grant military leave of absence and provide refunds for tuition and fees paid prior to active duty. Students are entitled to have their academic status restored upon completion of service without losing credits or scholarships. The "Reservist Opportunities and Protection of Education Act of 2003" mandates that institutions must grant military leave of absence and refund tuition. Students can have their academic status reinstated after service without losing credits or scholarships. Active duty definition and affected individual criteria are outlined in the act. The "Reservist Opportunities and Protection of Education Act of 2003" requires institutions to provide military leave of absence and tuition refunds for students serving on active duty during a war, military operation, or national emergency. The act defines terms like military operation, national emergency, and serving on active duty. The act requires institutions to provide military leave of absence and tuition refunds for students serving on active duty during a war, military operation, or national emergency, regardless of location. It includes members of the Armed Forces and National Guard on active duty in connection with the war or emergency. The National Guard duty during a war or military operation means full-time service for more than 30 consecutive days under a call to active service authorized by the President or Secretary of Defense. This duty is in connection with a war, military operation, or national emergency declared by the President and supported by Federal funds. Additionally, institutions must provide military leave of absence and tuition refunds for students on active duty during such times.
